back_matter.text: Long-term follow-up in patients with advanced Hodgkin's disease treated by high-dose chemotherapy followed by autologous peripheral blood stem cell transplantation L. Zenone Bragotti, A.A. Colombo, P. Bernasconi, D. Caldera, E. Brusamolino, C. Baratè, M. Bonfichi, M. Maffioli, A.A. Zaniboni, A. Algarotti, D. Troletti, M. Lazzarino, E. Alessandrino IRCCS Policlinico San Matteo (Pavia, I) Between September 1986 and December 2000, 53 patients with advanced Hodgkin's disease were treated with high dose chemotherapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation. We analyzed time to treatment failure, overall survival, treatment related complications and the occurrence of late events The median age of patients was 28 years ( range 13-58 ), 34 were males and 19 were females. Fifteen patients (Group A) were in second or subsequent CR, 29 patients (Group B) were with untreated relapse or resistant relapse, 10 patients (Group C) had primary refractory disease. All patients had received more than one line of therapy before transplant. Fifty-one pts were treated with Carmustine, Etoposide and Cyclophosphamide (CVB) given at the total dose of 600 mg/m², 30 mg/kg, 100 mg/kg respectively followed by autologous transplant. Two patients with primary refractory disease received Thiotepa and Melphalan. The overall response rate was 67% at three months after transplant The overall survival was 50% at 16 years. The probability of relapse for patients achieving complete remission was 39%. The median time to relapse was 182 days (range 120-519 days). At present 28 patients are alive, 5 died of transplant complications including death for secondary malignancy. The actuarial probability of developing second cancer was 8,2% at ten years (one solid tumor and one myelodysplasia). Overall survival and probability of relapse or progression according to status at transplant was as follows: Group A 65% and 32% ; Group B 49% and 44%; Group C 20%; 76%. Conclusion: better results were observed in patients receiving transplant in CR; in patients with untreated relapse or resistant relapse, high dose chemotherapy and autologous transplant can lead to durable remission. In patients with primary resistant disease, due to the high post transplant relapse rate, other therapeutic strategies should be investigated. Although the majority of patients with advanced HL achieve durable remissions and cure with conventional therapy, a subset will fail to enter remission or will relapse after an initial response. In the last decade high dose chemotherapy and stem cell transplantation has become the optimal therapy for this subgroup of patients. However, the superiority of megatherapy over conventional salvage strategies has not been proven in patients relapsing after a long first remission (i.e >1yr) or in patients with chemoresistant disease (partial remission <50%(PR), or primary refractory) and constitutes a matter of debate. Between 1992 and 2004, 54 patients with HL (males n=38, females n=16) with median age 31 years (17-58) were treated with megatherapy and autologus stem cell transplantation. Twelve (22%) had primary resistant disease, 40(74%) relapsed (17 <1yr, 23 >1yr) and two transplanted in first complete remission (CR) because of unfavorable clinical S242 characteristics(advanced stage, bulky disease). After salvage chemotherapy and before transplantation, 36 patients (67%) were evaluated as chemosensitive and 15 (28%) as chemoresistant. In thirty-three (61%)patients the conditioning regimen was CBV, in 18 (33%) BEAM and 3 received other combination. Twenty patients received bone morrow graft, 32 received peripheral blood and in 2 patients we administered both peripheral blood and bone morrow. Among 33 patients transplanted with residual disease (partial remission(PR), progressive disease), 25(78%) achieved CR, 3 PR and 3 were resistant. Two patients died of transplantrelated complications (TRM 3.7%). Among 25 complete responders, 10(40%) relapsed. Nineteen patients (35%) have died and 34(62%) are alive thirty of them (55%) in CR with a median follow-up of 97 months(16-129). One patient with progressive disease was lost in follow-up. The estimated 10year overall survival and event free survival(EFS) were 56% and 51.8% respectively. The difference in EFS was significantly better in chemosensitive group (66.4% vs 16.6%)(p<0.0001)( fig.1 ). Although longer follow-up is necessary to address ultimate cure rates and toxicity, these results from a single institution demonstrate the efficacy of high-dose therapy and autografting in refractory or recurrent HL. However, patients with chemoresistant disease before high dose therapy have a very poor prognosis.

cite_spans.text: Bragotti, A.A. Colombo, P. Bernasconi, D. Caldera, E. Brusamolino, C. Baratè, M. Bonfichi, M. Maffioli, A.A. Zaniboni, A. Algarotti, D. Troletti, M. Lazzarino, E. Alessandrino IRCCS Policlinico San Matteo (Pavia, I)

back_matter.text: Autologous stem cell transplantatnion in patients with relapsed or refractory Hodgkin's disease: a 10-year single-centre experience H. Minigo, R. Vrhovac, M. Kalac, B. Jaksic Clinical Hospital Merkur (Zagreb, HR) The chimeric monoclonal anti-CD20 antibody rituximab and the graft-versus-leukaemia/lymphoma effect after allogeneic stem cell transplantation have improved therapy of lymphatic malignancies dramatically during the last decade. In addition, successful therapy of chronic graft-versus-host disease after stem cell transplantation with rituximab has been published by one group. Other investigators correlated prolonged neutropenia after autologous stem cell transplantation to prior therapy with rituximab. To address the question, if rituximab pre-treatment prior to transplantation diminishes the graft versus lymphoma effect afterwards and can prolong engraftment of allogeneic haemopoiesis, we analysed retrospectively data from twentysix patients allografted for lymphoid malignancies. Seventeen patients had received at least one course of rituximab prior to allogeneic stem cell transplantation and nine did not. Both groups matched excellent for patients' characteristics. Preceding therapy with rituximab had no influence on eventfree survival (p=0,81), overall survival (p=0,87), or manifestation of acute (p=0,72) or chronic (p=0,50) graftversus-host disease after allogeneic stem cell transplantation. Patients with chronic graft-versus-host disease had a significantly better event-free survival (p=0,04) and overall survival (p=0,03) comparing to patients without. Patients with rituximab pre-treatment reached 1 leukocyte/nl significantly faster than patients without prior rituximab therapy (11 days [median, range 1-18] vs. 15 days [median, range 12-20], p=0,025, Mann-Whitney U-test). Engraftment of thrombocytes (TC) occurred as well faster after rituximab pre-treatment. The differences were significant for all three steps [20TC/nl: 11 days (median, range 1-24) vs. 27 days (median, range 11-33) p=0,013; 50TC/nl: 15 days (median, range 11-37) vs. 41,5 days (median, range 22-70) p=0,013; 100TC/nl: 19 days (median, range 13-44) vs. 58,5 days (median, range 25-177) p=0,008; Mann-Whitney U-test]. The mechanism leading to faster engraftment remains unclear so far. In conclusion, this investigation gives no hint for a suppression of GvH and GvL effects by rituximab administration prior to allogeneic stem cell transplantation. In addition, in contrast to results published for autologous stem cell transplantation, no detrimental effects on establishment of graft haemopoiesis after allogeneic stem cell transplantation by preceding rituximab therapy were found. Introduction: Children with B-cell NHL showing progression on the 1st and 2nd line chemotherapy have extremely poor prognosis as the patients with relapse of lymphoma. Highdose chemotherapy with autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) can improve the outcome of these patients. Addition of monoclonal anti-CD20 antibody (Rituximab) into "the bag" and after stem cell transfusion may decrease the risk of relapse by in vivo stem cell purging and adjuvant immunotherapy of MRD. Patients and methods: Since July 2000 to May 2005 8 patients (4 m, 4 f, median age 5(4-15)) with poor prognosis Bcell NHL -6 Burkitt, 1 BLCL and 1 with follicular DCL were included into the study. The indications for transplant wereresidual tumor mass after 4 cycles of intensive chemotherapy in 5 pts., early relapse in 1 patient, 2-nd relapse in 1 patient, progressive disease -1 patient). Five pts were pretreated with rituximab concomitantly with chemotherapy. Conditioning was with BEAM (BCNU, VP, cytosine arabinoside, melphalan) in 2 pts and Bu16,Cy,Vp in 6 pts. The stem cell sourse were peripheral blood cells (PBSC) mobilized with G-CSF alone. All patients have received Rituximab 375mg/m² on day (-1), 50 mg in the bag and 375mg/m² x 4 weekly after neutrophil recovery. Results: A median time to neutrophils recovery over 0,5x109/l was 18 days (8-30), and to platelets over 20x109/l -30 days (14-45). The main toxicity of conditioning were fever in 5pts (62%) (mean -3,8 days per febrile patient) and mucositis in 7 pts (87,5%). With a median follow-up of 2,5 year 7 pts are alive, all in CR. Overall survival (OS) and relapse-free survival (RFS) are 88% both. One patient transplanted in relapse progressed and died 2 month after transplant. There were no toxic deaths. Late effects. Two patients developed long lasting hypoimmunoglobulinemia and remain on IVIG transfusions at 42 and 26 mo. In 5 hypoimmunoglobulinemia resolved by 12 months after transplant. Conclusion: Rituximab is well tolerated in the scheme in HDT and ASCT and may have additional role in the treatment of children with high-risk lymphoma.

cite_spans.text: Minigo, R. Vrhovac, M. Kalac, B. Jaksic Clinical Hospital Merkur (Zagreb, HR)

back_matter.text: Remission of EBV associated post transplant lymphoproliferative disease confined to the brain after intravenously administered rituximab G. Stuhler (1) Background: Post transplant lymphoproliferative disease (PTLD) is a serious complication after allogeneic stem cell transplantation that can be controlled by anti CD20 antibody rituximab. In striking contrast, the treatment for PTLD confined to the brain is not established and current modalities reach from high dose chemotherapy to anti-viral drugs with limited efficiency. Patient: We report on a patient who developed progressively growing cerebral lesion in the postcentral region 2 years after allogeneic peripheral blood stem cell transplantation from a matched unrelated donor for mantle cell lymphoma stage IIIA. The diagnosis of post transplant lympho-proliferative disease (PTLD) confined to the brain was established by biopsy. Expression of CD20 on all transformed cells within the lesion and antigens associated with EBV latency program III was S244 confirmed by immunohistochemistry. After 4 cycles of intravenous treatment with rituximab 375 mg/m², a dramatic improvement of the neurological status was observed and MRI showed a remission with resolution of the contrastenhancing lesion. A small but significant population of CD8 positive T cells with specificity for EBV LMP2a but not LMP1 could be demonstrated after but not before rituximab therapy utilizing tetrameric peptide:HLA complexes and flow cytometry techniques. Conclusion: The clinical course of our patient with PTLD shows that rituximab given intravenously might be an effective therapy for EBV-triggered lymphoma of the CNS after allogeneic stem cell transplantation. The data indicate that sufficient amount of antibody penetrate the disrupted blood brain barrier and the nodular lesion observed here. The therapeutic effect appears to be limited to lesions with CD20 expression on all transformed cells. The inability of the host immune system to control PTLD was demonstrated. Methods: In this single center phase-II prospective study, high-dose therapy (HDC) and autologous peripheral blood stem cell transplantation (APSCT) was done during the first remission following induction and consolidation therapy for 18 patients with Burkitt (n: 5) and LL (n: 13) without bone marrow and central nervous system involvement at presentation. Cyclophosphamide, vincristine, prednisolone, adriamycin with or without L-asparaginase induction regimen was followed by dexamethasone, cytarabine, and cisplatin consolidation therapy with total body irradiation and cyclophoshamide conditioning. Results: Mean patient age was 24.6 (range: 21-55) years and male to female ratio was 5 to1. 44% (8/18) of the patients were in the intermediate and high-risk groups of International Prognostic Index. Median treatment duration until APSCT was 104 days (range: 87-128). 83% and 17% of the patients were in complete and partial remission before transplantation. One patient with Burkitt lymphoma out of 5 (20%) and 6 patients with LL out of 13 (46%) have died of progression. Overall survival (OS) at 113-month follow-up for all patients was 59.03% with 59.26% of disease-free survival (DFS). However, LL cases revealed OS and DFS rates of 50.35% and 50.77%, respectively. Only one early death (5.5%) was noted due to liver toxicity following HDC and APSCT. Conclusion: In conclusion, this single center phase-II study reveals an acceptable toxicity, short treatment period and high survival rate in adult Burkitt and LL cases, suggesting APSCT to be a good treatment option in the first remission. The optimal approach for patients (pts) with Hodgkin's lymphoma (HD) who do not achieve a complete remission (CR) or relapse after induction therapy is still not definite. Conventional schemes produce few second CR; recently the German Hodgkin Study Group produced good results with high-dose sequential chemotherapy (HDST) and autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) in this subset of pts. Since March 2002 to August 2005 15 pts were enrolled in this study in our Institution. The schedule was constituted by a first phase (2 cycles of DHAP), a second phase (cyclophosphamide 4g/sqm, methotrexate 8 g/sqm, etoposide 2g/sqm every 14 days) and an ASCT with BEAM conditioning. All phases but the ASCT one were delivered on outpatient basis. After the first phase a CT evaluation was performed to assess the chemosensibility: pts not achieving at least a partial response (PR) according to Cheson were considered off-study.Pts underwent leukapheresis after cyclophosphamide, and G-CSF 5 microg/Kg was administered from day +5 until collection. Pts status at the enrolment were: 7 relapsed within an year after the obtainment of CR; 6 refractory to the induction therapy (ABVD); 2 refractory to conventional salvage treatment for relapse occurred after 9 years. Characteristics of the pts at diagnosis were: median age (range) 28 years (19-42); 8 pts were female; 7 had B symptoms; ECOG performance status were 0 in 10 pts, 1 in four, 2 in one. All pts received the two cycles of DHAP without delays: after this phase 6 pts were excluded, 4 for stable/progressive disease, 2 for not achieving a PR (late relapsed pts: both are still alive with disease). The other nine pts completed the therapy according to the schedule; after the ASCT all of them were in CR with negative PET scans. A CR patient developed a myelodisplasia 13 months after the ASCT, shortly evolved in an acute leukaemia; this patient died because of acute graft versus host disease after a salvage allogeneic transplantation. The other eight CR pts are still without disease after a median observation of 667 days (range 82-1124). HDST is an effective therapy for treatment of relapsed and refractory HD pts. A longer follow-up is needed to evaluate the toxicity, especially the long-term myelotoxicity, and the real curative efficacy of this approach, which looks better in the relapsed pts.

One hundred sixty nine patients underwent autologous hemopoetic stem cell transplantation between December 1999 and November 2005. Eighty patients (49%) had Non Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL), 25-25 % had Hodgkin lymphoma and myeloma, 2 patients (1 %) had Ewing sarcoma. Eleven (14 %) among patients with NHL had anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL). Mean age of 7 male and 4 female patients was 35,7 years (23-52). Six patients had T-cell, four 0-cell and one B-cell phenotype. Eight patients had ALK negative, 2 ALK positive disease, 1 was not tested. Five patients were in remission, 5 had chemosensitive relaps and one patient had resistant disease at transplantation. Conditioning regimen was BEAM, TBI/Cyclophosphamide and BUCY in 8, 2 and 1 case, respectively. Peripheral blood stem cell (PBSC) was transplanted in 6, bone marrow (BM) in 4, mixed (both BM and PBSC) in 1 case. The mean stem cell count was 9,92x10 6 /kg CD34 positive cell in the graft of PBSC and 11,4x10
back_matter.section: P885 Autologous haemopoetic stem cell transplantation in anaplastic large cell lymphoma -a single-centre experience A. Szomor, M. David, H. Losonczy University Pecs (Pecs,HUN)

back_matter.text: Patients (pts) with diagnosis of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) and IPI age adjusted 2 or 3 present a poor prognosis. The results reported by Gianni et al. with high dose sequential therapy (HDST) showed a significant improvement of Overall Survival (OS) and Event Free Survial (EFS) in comparison with a standard chemotherapy. We decided to use this therapy adding an intensified scheme in the debulking phase. The first phase was constitued by an intensified CHOP (MegaCHOP): cyclophosphamide 3 g/sqm; doxorubicin 75 mg/sqm; oncovin 1,4 mg/sqm on day 1 and prednisone 100 mg for 5 days. Stem cells collection was planned after the third cycle. The second phase was: cyclophosphamide 4 g/sqm, methotrexate 8 g/sqm and VP16 2 g/sqm. The third phase was the peripheral blood stem cell transplantation (PBSCT) with melphalan 180 mg/sqm and mitoxantrone 60 mg/sqm as conditioning regimen. Inclusion criteria were: large B-cell lymphoma, age less than 50 years and intermediatehigh with bulky or high risk IPI. From March 2002 until February 2004 we enrolled 11 pts. Median age was 39 years (range 25-49), 8 pts were stage III-IV (73%), 7 presented bulky disease (64%), 9 pts had a WHO performance status 0-1 (82%), all but one had an abnormal LDH value. Four pts performed the first cycle with MegaCHOP as inpatients. All other cycles and the phase II were performed on outpatient basis. At the end of planned therapy 9 pts obtained a complete remission (CR) (82%), a patient after radiotherapy was alive with disease and one died of progressive disease during phase I. After first phase six pts obtained a very good partial remission (PR), after phase II six were in CR unconfirmed and 4 were in PR. After PBSCT 8 pts were in CR and 2 were in PR, one of this obtained a CR after mediastinal radiotherapy. After a median follow-up of 28 months (range 6-41) OS was 81%. Two pts died: one for progressive disease and one after relapse. With a median follow-up of 25 months 88% of complete remission pts were free from disease and only one patient relapsed after 2 months from CR. We did not find grade III or IV WHO extrahaematological toxicity. We can conclude that this protocol is feasible as outpatient basis in phases I and II. Moreover, this therapy was highly effective (81% OS) in a subset of pts with very high risk characteristics at diagnosis. Rituximab could further improve these results and could also be used in pts with involvement of bone marrow at diagnosis.
back_matter.section: . Saccardi, A. Vannucchi, A. Bosi Azienda Ospedaliera Careggi (Florence, I)

back_matter.text: Purpose: Refractoriness to platelet transfusions in patients undergoing myeloablative conditioning with consecutive hematopoietic progenitor cell (HPC) transplantation may represent a major problem in clinical management especially in case of immunization against frequent antigens. We report a case of a patient from Oman with an aggressive Non-Hodgkin lymphoma and a refractoriness to platelet transfusions solely caused by a Naka antibody. Case Report: A 36-year-old male patient with a diffuse large B-cell lymphoma and a history of previous chemotherapy and transfusions underwent mobilization chemotherapy with CD20 antibody rituximab and ICE combination chemotherapy. In aplasia surprisingly refractoriness to platelet transfusions (1 pool and 3 single donor apheresis platelet units) was observed.The patient's platelet count recovered spontaneously without bleeding complications and a sufficient number of HPC for transplantation could be harvested. Examinations of the patient's serum with enzyme immunoassays (GTI-PAK PLUS®) revealed an iso-antibody against CD36 (glycoprotein IV(GP IV)). Flow cytometric analyses showed that CD36 was absent on monocytes as well as on platelets suggesting a type I deficiency of CD36. In Europe GP IV-typed suitable donor were not available for the planned autologous HPC transplantation. Samples of six relatives living in Oman (2 siblings, 4 nephews) were shipped to Germany, tested, and 5/6 were found to be GP IV negative. Two relatives traveled to Germany and served as platelet donors. The patient was conditioned with BEAM and received 12.2E+06 CD34+ cells/kg. Due to infectious complications and a severe mucositis the patient was transfused with 9 single donor platelet units to maintain a platelet count > 10,000/µL in peripheral blood. On day +10 after transplant, leukocyte engraftment was observed and on day +17, the platelet count exceeded 50,000/µL without transfusion support. Conclusions: In patients with an ethnic background different from the European, investigations to elucidate refractoriness of platelet transfusions should include HLA antibodies, alloantibodies against HPA, and rare antibodies such as an anti-CD36. For patients with an anti-CD36 antibody, the most promising strategies to find suitable donors is to search among relatives or to search in countries with a higher prevalence of CD36 deficiency such as in Asia. Immunophenotyping for CD36 may be a rapid and helpful diagnostic tool in such instances.
back_matter.section: P887 Successful autologous peripheral blood stem cell transplantation of a patient with an isoantibody against CD36 (glycoprotein IV, Nak(a)) A. Humpe, B. Flesch, R. Repp, J. Miller, B. Gahn, N. Schub, M. Gramatzki University Clinics of Schleswig-Holstein Campus Kiel (Kiel, D)

back_matter.text: Treatment with Rituximab followed by autologous stem cell transfusion is an increasingly frequent association for treating non Hodgkin lymphomas either in first line or relapse. In a retrospective study, 166 (60.5%) patients treated between 1998 to 2003 who received Rituximab before transplantation (R-group) are compared to 108 (39.5%) patients Rituximab naive who underwent ASCT between 1994 to 1997 (Non-R group). We analyze the impact of Rituximab with that well known factors associated with or without successful mobilization of peripheral blood progenitor cells (lines of chemotherapy before transplantation, Fludarabine alone or associated therapy, bone marrow involvement) and with engraftment kinetics (number of CD34+ cells infused). For the study we divided patients from R and non-R group in 3 groups according to the richness of the collect: a low group with less than 2.5.106CD34+ cells/kg, a high group with greater or equal than 10.106CD34+ cells/kg and a standard group between 2.5 and 10 CD34+/kg harvested. In term of mobilisation, for the entire population, median CD34+ collected was 4,4.106 CD34+/kg (0,51-128). Fludarabine and number of previous treatment had a significantly negative impact on the harvest; 28, 5% of the patients previously treated by fludarabine are represented in the low group (p=0,008). When we compared R and non R group, we did'nt show any statistically difference in term of total number of CD34+ (p=0.373) but a significant difference in the repartition of patients between the three selected CD34+ groups (p<0.001). In term of engraftment, haematological recovery was significantly influenced by the richness of graft with a rapid recovery of neutrophils in the high group versus the two others (p<0,001) and a delay to obtain platelets>50000/mm³ in the low and standard groups versus the high (22 days, 15 days and 12) (p <0,001). We show a significant delay to neutrophils recovery in the R group (12 days vs 11 days) versus Non-R group (p= 0.0022) but no difference in term of Therapeutic use of cord blood (CB) is limited by low numbers of hematopoietic progenitor cells (HPCs). We developed a clinical system to expand CB HPCs using interleukin-6 (10 ng/ml), stem cell factor (50 ng/ml), Flt3 ligand (50 ng/ml) and thrombopoietin (10 ng/ml), in serum-free medium and 10% AB allogeneic plasma. After immunoselection (CliniMACS, Miltenyi Biotec), CD34+ cells are cultured for 2 weeks and the cytokines replaced twice a week. To evaluate the safety and efficacy of this experimental approach, we developed a phase I/II trial based on allogeneic transplantation of expanded CB HPCs. For safety reasons, only 1/3 of the CB unit is thawed, immunoselected and expanded. The negative fraction after CD34+ selection, that contains the T-cell component of the graft is thereafter transplanted, together with the unmanipulated and expanded cells. Three children, affected by thalassemia, sickle cell disease and refractory anemia with excess of blasts respectively, were given ex vivo expanded CD34+ cells from an HLA-identical sibling. The first patient, a 6-year-old boy with thalassemia, was given 2 CB units derived from 2 HLA-identical fraternal (i.e. non syngeneic) twins (1 unmanipulated CB unit and 1 CB unit infused after ex vivo expansion). CD34+ cells were cultured for 2 weeks in class B, ISO 6 laboratories. The mean+SD fold expansion of CD34+ cells were 48±15. The expanded grafts included 11.7±1.8x10 6 CD34+, 1.8±0.7x10 6 CD61+ cells and had a low lymphocyte content (CD3+ cells 2.5±1.3x10 4 ). The neutrophil and platelet engraftment time was 18±3 and 32±8 days respectively. In the first patient, chimerism evaluation showed the presence of erythroid and myeloid colonies derived from the ex vivo expanded cells up to 7 months after CBT; T cells deriving from the expanded unit were present at various time points after the allograft, as well. The patients are alive and well at 16, 9 and 6 months from transplantation. These results demonstrate that CB HPCs, safely and efficiently expanded with our system, can contribute to sustain hematopoietic recovery after CBT.
back_matter.section: P888 The role of rituximab in delayed neutrophils recovery after autologous stem cell transplantation A.S. Michallet, D. Bauwens, F. Bouafia-Sauvy, A. Duret, D. Espinouse, G. Salles, B. Coiffier Centre Hospitalier de Lyon-Sud (Pierre Bénite, F)

back_matter.text: In Korea, the cord blood stem cell transplantation (CBSCT) and cord blood (CB) banking projects was introduced since 1996 and 1997, respectively. We, in Korea, performed about 200 cases of CBSCT until May, 2005 and banked about 80,000 units of CB for public purposes, 170,000 units for private purposes. However, until yet we do not have had any national guideline nor regulations for CB banking to qualify the CB banks and assess the quality of stored CBs. We organized the Cord Blood Committee in the Korean Society of Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplantation at March, 2002. Based on the political research reports of our committee, the Ministry of Health and Welfare officially noticed the national guideline for CB banking on August, 2005. Also, the legislation was just drafted in the National Assembly by about 30 members of National Assembly. The essentials of the legislation drafted in this year are as follows: The purchase and sale of CB is prohibited (Article 3). The Cord Blood Committee is consisted in the Ministry of Health and Welfare to review the overall items regarding quality control as well as safety of CB. (Article 4) . The CB bank associates should get permission to establish CB banks from an Administrator of the Ministry of Health and Welfare (Article 5). The Administrator of the Ministry of Health and Welfare could establish or assign public CB banks to manage donated CBs (Article 6). The Public Cord Blood Data Center should be established to manage the informations regarding donated CBs, and to coordinate and supply CBs (Article 7). Mother, spouse or legal deputy should assign to permit CB collection and could abandon their consent at any time before collection (Article 8). The CB banks should adhere to the guidelines from the Ministry of Health and Welfare and provide donated cord bloods to the transplantation centers with nonprofit program (Article 11). The CB bank associates should keep the documents regarding CB banking until 10 years after releasing cryopreserved CB (Article 15, 16) . The government could provide budgets for public CB banking and networking projects, even the CB banks could claim the appropriate banking fees for private CBs (Article 27). Based on this statute, we could establish the National Public Cord Blood Banks as well as Networking System to supply the qualified CBs for domestic as well as foreign patients.

back_matter.text: Haemophagocytic syndrome; the most frequent cause of engraftment failure following reduced-intensity umbilical cord blood transplantation S. Takagi, S. Miyakoshi, K. Masuoka, D. Kato, Y. Matsuhashi, T. Kawano, Y. Oota, E. Kusumi, T. Matsumura, N. Uchida, A. Wake, A. Yoneyama, S. Morinaga, S. Taniguchi Toranomon Hospital (Tokyo, JP) Introduction: Haemophagocytic syndrome (HPS) is a rare but fatal complication after hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation (HSCT). There has been only a few case reports after HSCT and little information on it.It is widely accepted that transplantation using umbilical cord blood has lower engraftment rate than other stem-cell sources. Recently we have reported high incidence of HPS after reduced-intensity umbilical cord blood transplantation (RI-CBT) (2005 ASH annual meeting, #2743). We hypothesized that HPS played significant role in engraftment failure after RI-CBT. Objective, Patient and Methods: The purpose of this report is to study the causes of engraftment failure after RI-CBT. We reviewed medical records of 109 adult patients with advanced hematological diseases who received RI-CBT between January 2004 and October 2005 at Toranomon Hospital, Tokyo, Japan. Median age of the patients was 53 years old (23-69). Most of the preparative regimens were fludarabine phosphate 125 mg/m², melphalan 80 mg/m² and TBI 4 Gy. Tacrolimus was used as graft-versus-host disease prophylaxis in most of the cases. The median number of infused total nucleated cells (TNC) and CD34 positive cells was 2.65*10 7 cells/kg (1.67-5.24 ) and 0.65*10 5 cells/kg (0.11-3.90), respectively. Most of the donor-recipient pairs had serological mismatches at 2 HLA loci. Engraftment failure was defined as following; an absolute neutrophil count not exceeding 0.5*10 9 /L by day 21 after transplant. The diagnosis of HPS was S247 made with the followings; prolonged high grade fever, cytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly and liver dysfunction with histopathological evidence of increased activated histiocytes and hemophagocytosis in bone marrow. Results: Fifteen patients were diagnosed as engraftment failure after RI-CBT (13.8 %). Of 15 patients, 10 had the features of HPS (66.7 %). Among these, sepsis had preceded in 9 patients. Median interval from transplant to the diagnosis of HPS was 21 days (14-28). Of 10 patients with HPS, 8 were dead before engraftment. The remaining two patients were successfully treated with high-dose steroid. All of 7 patients without HPS died due to infection. Conclusion: HPS may play a major role in engraftment failure after RI-CBT. Since steroid therapy appears to be effective to some patients, an early diagnosis of HPS and prompt initiation of steroid could improve the outcome.

back_matter.text: Cellular recovery of thawed human cord blood in the transplantation setting: implications for haematopoietic reconstitution D. Rea, J. Larghero, M. Robin, C. Ferry, R. Traineau, V. Hubert, H. Esperou, C. Dosquet, J.P. Marolleau, G. Socie, E. Gluckman, M. Benbunan Hopital Saint-Louis (Paris, F) Cord blood (CB) is increasingly used as an alternative source of hematopoietic stem cells and the nucleated cell (NC) dose plays a key role in engraftment and survival. In 78 CB transplanted to 74 patients (median age 10 yo; range 1.5-44; median weight 32kg; range 10-90), we analyzed NC, CD34+ and CFU-GM recovery and viability. The impact of pre-and post-thaw cell dose on neutrophil recovery was analyzed. The median delay of cryopreservation was 1151 days (22-3145). Before cryopreservation, median NC, CD34+ and CFU-GM were respectively 1.84x10 9 (0.84-9.22), 5,43x10 6 (0.5-42) and 10x10 5 P894 Evaluation of viability in post thawed leukapheresis and cord blood units by flow cytometry G.L. Viarengo, C. Perotti, L. Bellotti, C. Parisi, A. Marchesi, V. Galiazzo, P. Bergamaschi, C. Del Fante, L. Salvaneschi Policlinico S. Matteo (Pavia, I) Objectives: Nowadays the role of flow cytometry in oncohematology is central. Detection of cell viability on cryopreserved stem cells (peripheral and cord blood) before chemoablative conditioning regimens needs more reliable methods. Herein we attempted to assess cell viability in post thawing samples by flow cytometry. Methods: 81 samples (55 leukapheresis, 26 cord blood) obtained from vials stored together with the cryopreserved units were diluted, immediately after thawing, with a PBS solution to 1:10 rate.The samples were promptly stained with anti CD45 FITC and anti CD34 III class PE MoAbs (BeckmanCoulter), then incubated at 4°C in darkness for 15' in TrueCount tubes (BD Biosciences) with a known number of beads to have an absolute single platform cell count. Samples were added with lysing solution and stained again with 7AAD (BeckmanCoulter). Flow cytometry analysis was performed immediately by BD Biosciences FACSCalibur according to S248 EWGGCA recommendations, that allow to obtain a single platform data of viability both on CD45 and CD34 positive cells. A comparison with Trypan Blue test on post thawing samples and pre-freezing short term cultures was assessed on every sample. Results: Mean viability assessed by flow cytometry in the leukapheresis group was 61,3% (range: 37,3-89,7), while in the cord blood group was 64,1%, (range: 39,3-81). Viability on CD45 positive cells was worse than on CD34 positive cells (61,3% versus 74%). Mean viability on leukapheresis samples, calculated by Tripan Blue test, was 80% (range: [70] [71] [72] [73] [74] [75] [76] [77] [78] [79] [80] [81] [82] , while on cord blood samples was 72% (range: 65-77). Clonogenic assays on pre-freezing samples showed an adequate CFU-GM, BFU-E and CFU-MIX growth for all samples seeded both in cord blood and leukapheresis group. Conclusion: Data obtained by flow cytometry analysis are not representative of the real stem cell viability because of the negative influence exerted by DMSO on stem cells during the sample thawing. Samples analysed post thawing by flow cytometry do not reflect the real status of stem cells inside the cryopreservation bag. At moment flow cytometry analysis of stem cells viability in post thawed leukapheresis and cord blood units is not reccommended. Post thawing tripan blue test together with pre-freezing short term cultures still remain the most representative test for clinicians involved in stem cell transplantation.

Viarengo, C. Perotti, L. Bellotti, C. Parisi, A. Marchesi, V. Galiazzo, P. Bergamaschi, C. Del Fante, L. Salvaneschi Policlinico S. Matteo (Pavia, I)

back_matter.text: Objectives: The side population (SP) phenotype resulting from efflux of the fluorescent dye Hoechst 33342 has been associated with high quality stem cells from both hematopoietic and non-hematopoietic organs. While expression of the transporter protein ABCG2 has been strongly implicated in the SP phenotype of bone marrow stem cells, relatively little is known about the SP in umbilical cord blood. The aim of this study was to establish a multi-channel FACS analysis procedure to determine the relationship between the side population phenotype and the expression of surface markers (CD45, CD34, CD133, ABCG2) in mononuclear cells from both fresh and cryopreserved umbilical cord blood. Methods: Mononuclear cells were prepared from fresh and cryopreserved umbilical cord blood, exposed to Hoechst 33342 for 2 hours, then stained with antibodies. Two-colour detection of the SP phenotype was then combined with fourcolour FACS analysis, forward and side scatter using a BD FACS Vantage to enable simultaneous detection of all relevant markers. Gene expression in sorted cell populations was determined by qRT-PCR. Results: SP cells were readily detectable in both fresh and cryopreserved blood, with a higher relative frequency following cryopreservation (0.78% versus 0.21%). While between 9.5% and 24% of the side population expressed either CD34 or CD133, the majority of the CD34+ and CD133+ cells were found outside the side population. There were no differences in either the relative frequencies or the distribution of CD34 and C D133 cells between fresh and cryopreserved blood. Both FACS and qRT-PCR analysis showed ABCG2 expression to be selectively absent from the SP cells. Conclusions: The SP of umbilical cord blood is heterogenous, but contains a subpopulation of the CD34+ and CD133+ cells. The SP as a whole appears to have a survival advantage during cryopreservation and recovery. The side population phenotype of umbilical cord blood is not attributable to ABCG2 expression.
back_matter.section: Cord blood side population cells are ABCG2 negative, and are maintained throughout cryopreservation and recovery procedures R. Alt (1), F. Wilhelm (1), O. Pelz-Ackermann (1), D. Egger (2), D. Niederwieser (1), M. Cross (1) (1)University of Leipzig (Leipzig, D); (2)Vita 34 AG (Leipzig, D)

back_matter.text: Improving outcome and lightening transplant burden: "transplant-lite" with dual unrelated umbilical cord blood in children P.-L. Tan, M.S. Villegas, E.-J. Yeoh, T.-C. Quah Children's Medical Institute (Singapore, SGP) Reduced intensity conditioning ("transplant-lite") with dual unrelated umbilical cord blood (UCB) transplantation was reported by the Minnesota group to be a feasible alternative for adult patients with haematological malignancies. The same strategy, if applied to children with very high risk acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (VHR ALL), may provide several advantages to conventional transplants, principally in ensuring engraftment, reducing transplant-related mortality, severe acute GVHD and relapse. We piloted this strategy in 4 children (median age, 9.5; range, 6.4-13.4 years) with VHR risk ALL. The preparative regimen consisted of cyclophosphamide 50mg/kg, fludarabine 200mg/m², 200cGy TBI +/-ATG as per Barker et. al. (Blood 2003) . UCB grafts were 0-2 HLA antigen mismatched with the recipient and contained a median cryopreserved total nucleated cell dose of 7.4 (range, 6.8-8.0) x 10 7 /kg and CD34 cell dose of 2.5 (range, 1.9-2.7) x 10 5 / kg recipient body weight. GVHD prophylaxis was with cyclosporine A and mycophenolate mofetil. The cumulative incidence of engraftment was 100%. The median day of sustained neutrophil recovery (≥ 0.5x10 9 /L for 3 days) was 10 (range, 6-12) days. The median day to achieving platelet engraftment (>50 x10 9 /L) and red blood cell transfusion independence were 73 (range, 31-175) and 30 (range, 0-77) days, respectively. All patients achieved 100% donor chimera by molecular studies at a median of 43 (range, 22-68) days. All patients developed steroid responsive acute GVHD of skin (grade II -III) at a median of 27 (range, 21-32) days. Herpes viruses re-activation was the only complication in heavily pre-treated, sero-positive patients. One patient relapsed on day 147 and achieved a 2nd remission on palliative chemotherapy. The average duration of hospital stay was 28 (range, 16-60) days. All patients are alive at a median follow-up of 203 (range, 84-301) days. These data demonstrated that "transplant-lite" with dual UCB is extremely safe and effective in grafting children with VHR ALL. Longer follow-up is required to evaluate relapse risks, graft-versusleukaemia and late effects. While long-term disease-free survival needs to be further determined, in comparison to conventional transplants, this strategy is superior in its toxicity profile and may eventually translate into overall life and costsavings.

back_matter.text: First two reported cases of systemic thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura following ablative unrelated cord blood transplantation C. Ferra, B. Xicoy, J.M. Sancho, M. Batlle, J.R. Grifols, A. Oriol, E. Feliu, J.M. Ribera ICO-H. Germans Trias i Pujol (Badalona, E) Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) is a well-known complication that may develop after hematopoietic progenitor transplantation (HPT) and seems to be related to immunosuppressive treatment (usually cyclosporine), chemotherapy, infectious events or GVHD. We present the first two reported cases of systemic TTP following unrelated cord blood transplantation (UCBT). Both cases were conditioned with thymoglobulin, cyclophosphamide, thiotepa and busulfan. GVHD prophylaxis was performed with cyclosporine and prednisone. Case 1: A 35-year-old male was diagnosed with Phi+ ALL in May 2003. He received an unrelated cord blood HPT when in 2nd CR in May 2004. He developed acute GVHD grade III involving the skin and gastrointestinal tract and was treated with prednisone 2 mg/kg/d and mycophenolate mofetil. He suddenly presented drowsiness and CT scan was negative. There was a sudden drop in platelet count and hemoglobin.From July 1995 to September 2005, 30 patients with high risk ALL aged < 18 years, underwent cord blood transplantation (CBT) from unrelated, <2 antigens HLA mismatched donors. Twenty patients were in < 2nd complete remission (CR), 10 in more advanced phase. Conditioning regimen (12 Gy f-TBI, Etoposide, CTX and anti-lymphocyte serum), GVHD prophylaxis (CsA and 6-methylprednisolone), infectious disease prevention and supportive therapy were identical for all patients. The median number of infused nucleated cell and CD34+ cells/Kg were 3.7x107and 3.4x105/Kg of the recipient body weight, respectively. The median number of infused CFU-GM was 1.9x104/Kg of recipient body weight. The cumulative incidence of engraftment was 88% (95%CI:0.78-0.85). The cumulative incidence of acute-GVHD (III-IV grade) and chronic-GVHD was 4% (95%CI: 0.03-0.36) and 33% (95%CI: 0.07-0.48), respectively. At a median follow-up of 15 months (range 2-117) after transplant ,16 patents are dead and 14 patients are alive and disease free (median f-up 69 months) with full donor chimerism. The cumulative incidence of TRM and relapse at 7 years is 33% (95%CI:0.13-0.45) and 32%(95%CI:0.26-0.67), respectively. The 7-year probabilities of overall survival (OS), leukaemia-free-survival (LFS) and event-free-survival (EFS)were43%(95%CI:0.52-0.93),47%(95%CI:0.25-.41)and46%(95%CI:0.33-0.61) respectively. In univariate analysis, the only factor negatively affecting outcomes was the CFU-GM for the cut-off dose of < 1x104/Kg of recipient body weight. Conclusions: CBT is a valid option in the treatment of high risk ALL young patients who lack of a compatible donor. The cell dose expressed as CFU-GM is predictive of outcomes and should be considered in selecting cord blood units for transplant.

cite_spans.text: J.M. Sancho, M. Batlle, J.R. Grifols, A. Oriol, E. Feliu, J.M. Ribera ICO-H. Germans Trias i Pujol (Badalona, E)

back_matter.text: Haploidentical transplantation for children with refractory haematologic malignancies G. Hale, X. Chen, E. Benaim, P. Woodard, K. Kasow, E. Horwitz, W. Leung, U. Yusuf, R. Barfield, R. Hayden, J. Knowles, F. Behm, S. Shurtleff, V. Turner, R. Handgretinger St. Jude Children's Research Hospital (Memphis, USA) Conditioning for allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) has historically used ablative regimens, which can cause severe toxicity and mortality, especially in highly pre-treated patients. Reduced intensity conditioning regimens (RICR) for partially HLA-matched transplants have not been widely explored. In 2 simultaneous prospective trials, we transplanted 34 patients with hematologic malignancies using peripheral blood grafts from mismatched family members depleted of T cells with immunomagnetic beads targeting CD3+ cells, and containing high doses of CD34+ cells. 22 patients in RICR group (mean age 10yrs) had refractory diseases and received fludarabine, thiotepa, melphalan and OKT3 without TBI and ATG. Mycophenolate mofetil was used for GvHD prophylaxis. 12 patients in conventional conditioning regimen (CCR) group (mean age 11 yrs)received TBI (12 Gy), cyclophosphamide, thiotepa, ATG and OKT3 with cyclosporine GvHD prophylaxis. Monthly analysis of immune reconstitution included TREC, VBeta spectratyping and lymphocyte immunophenotyping. Weekly monitoring of blood by PCR for adenovirus, EBV, or CMV DNA was performed. After HSCT, 91% (20/22) RICR pts achieved full donor chimerism compared with 92% (11/12)of CCR pts. 2/22 (9%) RICR pts developed grade 3-4 acute GvHD compared to 0/12 CCR pts. Only 5 pts (all in RICR group) developed chronic GvHD. Reactivation of 1 or more viruses occurred in 16/22 (73%) RICR pts compared to 11/12 (92%) CCR pts. During the first 2 months after HSCT, all Tcell(CD3+, CD4+, CD8+)populations were decreased in both groups with the RICR groups having levels 25-73 times greater than the CCR group (p<0.0086). At one month after HSCT, NK cells were 4 times higher in the RICR group (p=0.01); NK cells remained 1.6 to 4 times higher in the RICR group for the entire 1st year. B cells in both groups were normal by 3 months post-HSCT. TREC counts were below normal pre-HSCT in 13/22(59%)RICR pts and in 5/12 (42%)CCR pts. TCR repertoire was significantly greater at 3 months post-HSCT in the RICR group(p=0.092). This welltolerated RICR approach led to more rapid reconstitution of Tcells, early re-emergence of TREC numbers with early recovery of TCR repertoire diversity, more rapid NK cell number increase rapidly leading to a reduced incidence and duration of viral infections with less GvHD compared to CCR. This approach offers the possibility of improved anti-cancer immune effect with less regimen-related toxicity. During the past decade, transplantation of highly purified peripheral haploidentical stem cells has become a well established treatment procedure in many children with malignant and non malignant diseases. Positive enrichment of peripheral stem cells by anti-CD34 or CD133 magnetic micro S251 beads provides a graft profoundly depleted of T and B cells facilitating engraftment without inducing severe GVHD. However, despite transplanting "mega doses" (>10 6 /kgBW) of positive enriched stem cells, primary graft rejection and, delayed immune recovery associated with increased transplant related mortality remained major obstacles for the success of this therapeutic approach. As reported before, primary engraftment could be achieved in 88% and after reconditioning in 100% of 27 children with ALL transplanted with "mega-doses" (median: 16.4E6/kgBW; range 5.4-50.4) of positive enriched stem cells from their HLA-haploidentical parents. All patients received G-CSF post transplant and achieved more than 500 ANC/µl 12 days post transplant (range, 8-24) . All patients achieved more than 100 CD3+ and CD4+ cell/µl after median time of 67 and 101 days, respectively. Three year EFS of patients transplanted in remission (n=21) was 0.43 (+ 0.11). In contrast to positive selection of stem cells, grafts after depletion of CD3/CD19 cells consist of remarkable amounts of effector cells. These effector cells are expected to facilitate engraftment, shorten the time of immune reconstitution and may also provide anti tumour activity. Here we report on our experience with 10 children (ALL, n=4; AML, n=2; rhabdomyosarcoma, n=2 and aplastic anaemia, n=2) receiving CD3/CD19 depleted peripheral stem cell grafts (median number of 10.6E6/kgBW CD 34+ cells (range, 4.6-20.0)). Grafts also contained NK-cells (median number: 17.19E6/kgBW), dendritic cells, precursor T-cells and monocytes/granulocytes (median number: 446.45E6/kgBW). Without the administration of G-CSF, all 10 patients achieved rapid and sustained engraftment with more than 500 ANC/µl and more than 20.000/µl thrombocytes at day 16.5 and 16.75, respectively. All patients showed a complete chimerism post transplant at day 28. Median time to achieve more than 100 CD3+ and CD4+ cells/µl was 51.0 and 53.5 days, respectively. Nine out of 10 children are alive and well, one patient died on day +156 post transplant of relapsed AML.

(range, 8-24)

back_matter.text: Role of haploidentical stem cell transplantation in children with severe combined immunodeficiency T. Cobo, R. Arrieta, A. Kerguelen, I. Galindo, A. Marcos, F. Hernandez-Navarro Hospital Universitario La Paz (Madrid, E) Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID) represents several genetically distinct congenital birth defects what are an important cause of childhood mortality and is a time pediatric emergency. Is the focus of active investigation using altenative stem cell sourcer for most patients took matched sibling donors. We report our experience in nine cases of SCID that were underwent to haploidentical transplant in our centre. Median age at transplant was 16,6 months, (range 7m to 48m). The median follow up period is 50, 5 months (range 1-113), and SCID consecutive cases are described in table. All of them were transplant from haploidentical family donors from peripheral mobilized HLA-mismatched CD34 progenitors isolated. The separation of CD34+ cells from leukapheresis products was achieved in almost all patients (7/9) by the Clinimacs System (Miltenyi) with a CD34+ cell purity range of 93-98% and range of yield of 64% to 97%. The mean value of peripheral CD34+ cells infused was 28.6 x 106/kg (range 5,05-44,31) and the mean CD3+ cells number was 1,24 x 105/kg (range 0,15-2,17) with mean 4,09 log T cell-depletion ( range 3.63-4.64), the remaining patients (2/9) we used Ceprate and Isolex 300 system (Baxter) respectively. Conditioning regimen was undergone in five patients, only one case received prophylaxis for graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) with cyclosporine (patient nº 1). Survival rate was 47% and at least all of patients survived from 1 month to 14 months posttransplantation and also engraftment achieved in almost all treated patients(7/9 =74,8%) between day +15 to +20.Skin GVHD (grade I) was seen in only two patients. Causes of death were: two cases of graft rejection that needed a second transplant and finally they had a metabolic acidosis and lung bleeding respectively, one VOD, and two sepsis. We concluded that the engraftment achieved in almost all treated patients, and the acceptable conditioning-related toxicity suggests that this approach could be successfully applied to children affected by SCID who otherwise have no suitable donors. F. Aversa, A. Terenzi, S. Ballanti, A. Tabilio, A. Carotti, M. Di Ianni, F. Falzetti, T. Aloisi, J. Saab, A. Santucci, F. Martelli University of Perugia (Perugia, I) Haematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) from a onehaplotype mismatched donor offers an immediate source of HSCs to almost all leukemia patients who urgently need an allogeneic transplantation because of the high-risk of relapse and who do not have a matched avaible donor. Over the past decade, our group has shown the two major obstacles to mismatched transplants, that is severe acute GVHD in T-cellreplete transplants and graft rejection in T-cell-depleted transplants, can be overcome by infusing a megadose of extensively T-cell-depleted HSCs after an immuno-myeloablative conditioning regimen. Here we report results in 56 AML (25 CR1, 21 CR2, 10 CR>2), 34 ALL (17 CR1, 15 CR2, 2 CR>2) and 10 CML (6 CP, 4 AP) who have been transplanted since 1999 when we started selecting peripheral blood CD34+ cells by the clinimacs instrument which ensures a 4.5 log T-cell depletion in a one-step procedure. Conditioning consisted of single dose TBI, thiotepa, fludarabine and rabbit ATG. T-cell depletion was the sole prophylaxis of GvHD. Median age was 35 (range 11-59) years. Early stages included CR1, CR 2, first and second chronic phase of CML; intermediate stages were CR>2 and accelerated phase CML. All CR1 acute leukemia were at high risk of relapse because unfavorable prognostic factors (cytogenetics in 21, secondary leukemia in 9, others in 9); the 10 CML, who were imatinib and/or INF resistant, have received the transplant more than 3 years from diagnosis. Full-donor engraftment was achieved in 99% of patients including 4 who needed secondary transplants. Without a post-transplant immunosuppression, probability of acute grade II-IV GvHD and chronic GvHD was 5% and 6%, respectively. 36 patients died of non-leukemic cause, 17 of leukemia relapse, 47 survive disease-free at a median follow-up of 38 months (range 2-83). Probability of EFS was 0.32, 0.48 and 0.66 for early ALL, AML and CML, respectively; it was 0.0, S252 0.48 and 0.50 for the intermediate ALL, AML and CML, respectively. Of the 6 CML patients, only 3 required DLI because of cytogenetic relapse; the other are in molecular remission 8, 57 and 81 months since transplantation. HSCT from a mismatched family member can be offered as a viable option to candidates with high risk acute leukemia and with imatinib-resistant CML before diseases progress to more advanced phases.

back_matter.text: An ultra-violet reverse phase HPLC method for detection, dose determination and clinical application of busulfan in human plasma: variability of exposure to daily IV busulfan and influence of high exposures on transplantrelated mortality F. Naveed, S. Kangarloo, M. Geddes, D. Quinlan, J. Russell Alberta Blood Cell & BMT Program (Calgary, CAN) An isocratic High Performance Liquid Chromatographic (HPLC) method was successfully developed in order to quantify Busulfan (Bu) levels in human plasma by detection of its chemical derivative 1,4-bis(diethyldithiocarbamoyl butane). The concentration of drug in human plasma was measured with UV detection at 278nm by employing a Waters Nov-Pak C-18 analytical column heated to 40oC. The mobile phase, run at 1.5mL/min, consisted of a mixture of 20:80 deionized water and methanol respectively. The retention times for Bu and the internal standard were 6.7 and 8.8min, respectively. All concentration-time plasma Bu data were analyzed by noncompartmental analysis using WinNonlin Version 4.1 software (Pharsight Corporation, Mountain View, CA, USA). Analyses were performed on 125 allogeneic Stem-Cell Transplant (SCT) patients (pts). All pts received fludarabine 50mg/m² on days -6 to -2 and IV Bu (Busulfex, ESP Pharma) at a "myeloablative" dose of 3.2mg/kg daily, on days -5 to -2 inclusive. Additional TBI 200cGy x 2 was given to 48 pts. Graft-vs.-host disease prophylaxis for all pts comprised cyclosporine A, "short course" methotrexate with folinic acid and Thymoglobulin (Genzyme) 4.5mg/kg in divided doses over 3 consecutive days pre-transplant finishing D0. The range of AUC per dose was 2184 to 7513 (median 4731) uM*min. Nineteen pts (15%) had AUC <3600uM*min and 15 (12%) had AUC >6000uM*min. The remaining 91 (73%) were between 3600 and 6000uM*min, equivalent to an exposure of 900-1500uM*min per dose established as desirable from studies of qid oral Bu given with cyclophosphamide. Transplant-related mortality in the pts with AUC >6000uM*min was significantly greater than in the pts with lower exposures (39±14% vs. 15±4%, p = 0.03). Given its good reproducibility the analysis method is efficient and cost effective for PK studies. Although IV Bu gives more predictable exposure than PO Bu this regimen still results in a 3-4 fold variability in AUC and a significant proportion of pts with exposures previously deemed too high or low when PO Bu is given with cyclophosphamide. These results also suggest that high exposures (> 6000uM*min) may increase the risk of transplant-related death and provide some justification for therapeutic monitoring.

cite_spans.text: Naveed, S. Kangarloo, M. Geddes, D. Quinlan, J. Russell Alberta Blood Cell & BMT Program (Calgary, CAN)

back_matter.text: Occurrence and severity of adverse events following autologous haematopoietic stem cell infusion is related to the amount of granulocytes in the apheresis product B. Calmels (1) Adverse events following hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) infusion are rare but might be severe. These reactions have been associated to the amount of cryoprotectant infused, but persistence of such events after DMSO depletion have questioned this assumption. We prospectively evaluated the incidence of side effects for 354 consecutive patients (372 HSC infusions) undergoing autologous HSC transplantation for hematologic or solid malignancies at two institutions. Side effects following infusion of HSC grafts thawed and washed at the laboratory were reported by medical teams in 50 cases (13%), and were graded according to the NCI-CTC from 1 to 4. While none of the factors associated with patient characteristics or infusion procedure -such as the volume infused or the infusion flow -are different between the two groups (grade 0 vs grade 1 to 4), we found that the absolute number of granulocytes (PMNC) measured before freezing is considerably higher in the adverse events group (n=50, av. 38.10e9 PMNC) compared to the other (n=322, av. 13.10e9 PMNC, p<10 9 ). Furthermore, within the adverse event group, there is a strong correlation between the amount of PMNC and the severity of the reaction (n=41 for grades 1/2, av. 32.10e9 PMNC; n=9 for grades 3/4, av. 64.10e9 PMNC, p=0.006). Others parameters associated with the occurrence of side effects are post-thaw viability (p<10 7 ), absolute number of CD45+ cells before freezing (p=0.02) and CD34+ cells recuperation (p=0.02). Of note, incidence and severity of adverse reactions when using the CytoMate cell washer (n=82 procedures, 16% of grades 1 to 4), that remove more than 95% of DMSO (Calmels et al., 2002) , is identical to those reported when washing HSC grafts using a less efficient manual centrifugation technique (n=209 procedures, 16% of grades 1 to 4). Although the presence of PMNC in apheresis products is undesirable, the clinical consequences of such contaminations have rarely been evaluated. This survey demonstrates that adverse reactions occuring in the setting of DMSO-depleted HSC grafts are related to the amount of PMNC and thus emphasizes the need for high-quality apheresis products so as to improve the safety of HSC infusion. Our observations suggest that immediate toxicity after infusion is probably of multifactorial origin and implies that pre-infusion washing of HSC grafts, that cannot remove PMNC remnants, might not be enough to reduce infusion-associated complications. Introduction: Engraftment syndrome (ES) is an increasingly reported complication of hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). However, there are no uniform definitions of the diagnosis criteria and there are contradictory reports relating to the incidence of the syndrome and the risk factors. Moreover, the pathophysiologic mechanism of ES has not been studied. Methods: In order to characterize the clinical criteria for the diagnosis of ES and the risk factors for its occurrence, we prospectively followed 94 HSCT recipients, autologous 52%,a nd allogeneic 49%. In addition, we have measured the levels S253 of the soluble alpha subunit of the interleukin-2 receptor (sIL-2Ralpha)ƒnƒw known as an early and reliable marker of T-cell activation, prior to transplant and then on day 0, and upon engraftment. Results: Based on a univariate and multivariate analyses model we defined diagnostic criteria for the development of the syndrome. Following these criteria, patients were diagnosed as having definite ES when having noninfectious fever, maculopappular skin rash and >3% weight gain during the period of stem cell engraftment. Patients were diagnosed as having probable ES when having noninfectious fever plus one of the two other criteria. Using these criteria the incidence of ES was 18%. Importantly, ES occurred only following autologous HSCT in multivariate analysis. The risk factors for the diagnosis of ES were the diagnosis of non Hodgkin lymphoma, p=0.03, O.R. 9.8(0.8-116) and BEAC/BEAM as conditioning regimens, p=0.01 O.R. 11.2 (1.7-106.7). The ratio between the level of sIL-2Ralpha ƒnas the day of engraftment and baseline was significantly higher in patients who developed definite or probable ES (collectively), when compared to those who did not (p=0.004). Conclusions: Based on this prospective study we suggest novel diagnostic criteria for engraftment syndrome. In addition, we have indicated certain risk factors for the development of ES. Importantly, based on the measurements of sIL-2Ralphaƒn we imply that T-cell activation plays a pivotal role in the pathophysiologic mechanism of the syndrome. Finally, we suggest sIL-2Ralpha ƒnmay be a potential marker for the development of the syndrome.

cite_spans.text: DMSO (Calmels et al., 2002)

back_matter.text: High transplant-related mortality in heavly pre-treated acute lymphoblastic leukaemia patients S. Guidi, B. Bartolozzi, G. Gianfaldoni, F. Leoni, L. Lombardini, C. Nozzoli, R. Saccardi, A.M. Vannucchi, A. Bosi AOU Careggi (Florence, I) Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) in acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) is still controversial and the main policy is to reserve it for high-risk or advanced patients (pts). To evaluate the efficacy and the mortality of HSCT, we analysed 79 consecutive pts affected by ALL referred to our BMT Unit for transplant from March 1989 to December 2004. 49 were male, 30 female; median age was 29 yrs (range 16-54). 53 pts had B-lineage ALL, 26 T-lineage. The Philadelphia chromosome (Ph) was present in 20 pts (25%). According to the German ALL risk classification, 28 pts were classified as standard risk, 31 high risk and 20 very high risk. 43 pts (54%) received transplantation in > CR1; 35 pts (44%) received more than 3 cycles of chemotherapy before the transplant procedure. The donor was in 52 patients an HLA-related identical sibling (IS) and in 27 pts an unrelated matched donor (UD). Stem cell source was in the majority bone marrow (82%). The conditioning regimen was ifTBI 1320 cGy and CY120 (addition of VP-16 50 mg/mq in 7 advanced IS pts). GvHD prophylaxis was CYA/MTX; in UD transplant group ATG was added. As regard the disease status, pts in> CR1 were 27 (51%) in the IS group and 16 (59%) in the UD group; 19 (37%) and 16 pts (59%) had received more than 3 cycles respectively in the IS and in the UD group. With a median follow-up of 14 months (range , the event free survival at 3 years (EFS) was 37% (median 7 months). The EFS for IS was 43% (median 12 months) and for UD 26% (median 6 months) (p=.04). The overall TRM was 23%; 12% in IS transplant vs 44% in UD (p=.0001); according to disease status, TRM was 11% for pts transplanted in first CR vs 33% for pts in more advanced phase of disease (p=.04). A significant difference in term of TRM was also documented in pts that received more than 3 courses of chemotherapy compared to the others (43% vs 7%) (p=.0007). In multivariate analysis, considering age, sex, immunophenotype, risk class, disease status, number of CT courses, type of BMT, number of CD34 cell infused, sex-match and CMV status, the only factors influencing TRM were the number of CT courses (p=.003; H.R: 6.5; CI 95%: 1.8-23) and the type of transplant (p=.01; H.R. 3.4; CI 95%: 1.26-9.26). These results suggest that allogeneic myeloablative transplant should be performed earlier, beginning therefore an unrelated donor search as soon as possible, in order to reduce the number of CT courses and so the TRM.

cite_spans.text: Guidi, B. Bartolozzi, G. Gianfaldoni, F. Leoni, L. Lombardini, C. Nozzoli, R. Saccardi, A.M. Vannucchi, A. Bosi AOU Careggi (Florence, I)

back_matter.text: Pathogenetic factors in the development of hepatic venoocclusive disease in patients undergoing haematopoietic stem cell transplantation M. Dávid, O. Tóth, Á. Szomor, Á. Nagy, H. Losonczy University of Pécs (Pécs, HUN) Research in the pathogenesis of hepatic veno-occlusive disease (VOD) has recently focused on four different areas, like the role of glutathione depletion and inflammatory mediators in the process and the activation of fibrogenesis and blood coagulation system. Our aims were to perform thrombophilia studies and examine the role of inflammatory mediators before SCT, to investigate endothelial function and fibrogenesis before and 10 days after SCT and compare the data of patients with and without hepatic VOD. Number of patients: 103, mean age: 41.13±14.68 years, male/female ratio: 56/47. The indications for autologous transplantation were non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in 41, Hodgkin's disease in 34, multiple myeloma in 26 and Ewing sarcoma in 2 patients. Thrombophilia studies (before SCT): fibrinogen, APC resistance, Antithrombin, Protein C, Protein S activity and antigen, lupus anticoagulant, FV:Q506 (Leiden mutation), FII 20210A allele and MTHFR C677T mutation. TNF-alpha gene d allele polymorphism: microsatellite method. Tests for endothelial dysfunction: PAI-1 and vWF antigen (before and 10 days after SCT), plasma homocystein level. Test for fibrogenesis: N-terminal propeptide of type III procollagen (PIIINP) RIA. Six patients (5.8%) developed hepatic VOD. 70% (72/103) of patients had abnormality in the thrombophilia studies, 34% (35/103) showed combined defects. Three abnormalities had higher prevalence than in the general population: high fibrinogen levels in 20% (21/103), type II Protein C deficiency in 12% (13/103) and hyperhomocysteinaemia (HHC) in 46.6% (48/103) with MTHFR C677T mutation in only 35% (17/48). The vWF antigen levels were high before SCT and increased significantly (p< 0.0002) afterwards. The PAI-1 antigen and the PIIINP levels increased markedly in patients with VOD, but remained unchanged in patients without it (p=0.24). There was no statistically significant difference in the TNFd3 allele frequency between the general population (47%) and our patients (54%) (p= 0.54). The marked HHC could be attributed to acquired factors, but folate levels remained normal. The prevalence of MTHFR C677T mutation was not higher than in the general population. The endothelial damage caused by high dose therapy and HHC resulted in an elevated vWF and PAI-1 Ag levels. We could not prove the importance of TNF gene polymorphism, but PAI-1 antigen and PIIINP levels had predictive role in the development of hepatic VOD.

cite_spans.text: Dávid, O. Tóth, Á. Szomor, Á. Nagy, H. Losonczy University of Pécs (Pécs, HUN)

back_matter.text: Can fludarabine replace alkylating agents when combined with standard doses of busulfan (16 mg/kg) as conditioning therapy before allogeneic stem cell transplantation? A retrospective matched-pair comparison M. Bornhäuser, C. Theuser, T. Illmer, A. Kiani, M. Schaich, J. Schetelig, T. Wolf, R. Ordemann, F. Kroschinsky, C. Röllig, A. Helwig, J. Babatz, J. Freiberg-Richter, A. Jenke, U. Schuler, U. Platzbecker, G. Ehninger Universitätsklinikum Dresden (Dresden, D) Objectives: Busulfan (BU) at doses of 12-16 mg/kg combined with 120-200 mg/kg Cyclophosphamide (CY) has been established as the most frequently used conditioning protocol for allogeneic transplantation. Efforts to decrease extramedullary toxicities especially in older patients have lead to the introduction of Fludarabine (FLU) as a potential alternative compound mediating immunosuppressive effects to allow for engraftment of allogeneic stem cells from related and unrelated donors. Recent studies have suggested that FLU can be safely combined with standard doses of oral and intravenous BU. The aim of our study was to retrospectively compare both regimens applied at a single institution. Patients and Methods: Either FLU 120 mg/sqm or CY 120 mg/kg were combined with 16 mg/kg oral or 13,8 mg/kg intravenous BU in 62 patients with myeloid malignancies. The two cohorts (n=31 each) were matched for disease (19 AML, 8 MDS, 4 CML), cytogenetic risk, number of previous chemotherapy regimens (n =2), donor sex and graft source. The median age was 54 years (range 24-66) in the FLU/BU group and 48 (range 27-63) in the BU/CY group. Etoposide 30 mg/kg was added to BU/CY in 9 patients and 7 patients in this group received ATG during conditioning therapy. GvHD prophylaxis was comparable with CsA/Mtx or CsA/MMF. The proportion of matched sibling donors was significantly higher in the BU/CY group (21/31 vs. 6/31, p<0.0001). Results: Neutrophil engraftment was significantly faster in the BU/CY group (12 vs. 14 days, p=0.001). Platelet engraftment was comparable in both groups. The incidence of renal and liver toxicity as well as grade 3-4 mucositis during the first 30 days after transplantation did not differ significantly. Although a higher proportion of unrelated donors was selected in the FLU/BU cohort, the rate of acute GvHD grade II-IV tended to be lower compared to BU/CY patients (52% vs. 65 %, p=0.3). Chronic GvHD occurred in 14 (FLU/BU) and 15 patients (BU/CY) patients, respectively. The probability of disease-free survival at 24 months was not significantly different (32% FLU/BU vs. 38% for BU/CY). The same was true for nonrelapse mortality and probability of relapse. Conclusion: This retrospective comparison suggests that CY can be replaced by FLU in combination with 16 mg/kg BU and that the FLU/BU regimen has comparable clinical efficacy. Whether specific subgroups may benefit more from one or the other regimen has to be studied prospectively.

cite_spans.text: Bornhäuser, C. Theuser, T. Illmer, A. Kiani, M. Schaich, J. Schetelig, T. Wolf, R. Ordemann, F. Kroschinsky, C. Röllig, A. Helwig, J. Babatz, J. Freiberg-Richter, A. Jenke, U. Schuler, U. Platzbecker, G. Ehninger Universitätsklinikum Dresden (Dresden, D)

back_matter.text: Haemolysis as complication of conditioning regimens containing ATG (Fresenius) M. Navratil, Z. Koristek, M. Tomiska, M. Doubek, M. Krejci, Y. Brychtova, J. Mayer Dpt.of Internal Medicine Hematooncology (Brno, CZ) Introduction and Methods: ATG is a part of many ablative as well as nonmyeloablative regimens and several side effects of this drug are described. However, ATG-caused acute hemolysis has not been systematically studied. During the year 2005, we saw several causes of hemolysis, sometimes severe, being very suspicious to be caused by ATG. Therefore, we decided to review retrospectively all transplantations performed at our Dept. from Jan 2006 to Sept. 2005 and to search the hemolytic reactions probably caused by ATG.Results: Twenty-three patients (pts) were eligible (Bu+Flu+ATG, n=20; Cy+ATG, n=2; Bu+Cy, n=1), transplanted mostly for myeloid malignancies (n=15; other diagnoses: aplastic anemia: n=2, CLL: n=4, NHL: n=2). None of these patients showed any signs of hemolysis before ATG administration. ATG (Fresenius) was given mainly at the dose 10 mg/kg/day for 4 consecutive days. Two days after the last dose of ATG, 16 pts (70%) showed elevated bilirubin levels, 9 of them had elevated LDH. In 4 pts, free plasma hemoglobin and haptoglobin were evaluated and in all pts the results were compatible with hemolysis. Eighteen (78%) pts showed decrease in hemoglobin level more than 20 g/L on the 2nd day after the ATG administration. Five pts (22%) showed laboratory and clinical signs of florid fierce hemolysis and one developed acute renal insufficiency. Moreover, all of them had problems with red blood cell transfusion compatibility. The immunohematological investigation demonstrated nonspecific antibodies bond on the erythrocytes with the activation of complement. Direct antiglobulin test was positive in all 5 cases. All of these pts had to be given more than 5 units of packed red blood cells and 2 pts were treated with pulse corticosteroids. Other 9 pts showed clinical and laboratory signs of mild hemolysis not requiring massive substitution. Conclusion: Despite the retrospective nature of this study, hampering the exact description of all hemolysis-related laboratory phenomena, it is clear that ATG given in the peritransplant period can be frequently linked with the signs of hemolysis, severe in about one fifth of the pts and requiring therapy. Further studying of this potentially life-threatening complication is warranted.

cite_spans.text: Navratil, Z. Koristek, M. Tomiska, M. Doubek, M. Krejci, Y. Brychtova, J. Mayer Dpt.of Internal Medicine Hematooncology (Brno, CZ)

back_matter.text: Treosulfan-based conditioning regimen can replace TBI for studying the plasticity of bone marrow cells using EGFP transgenic mice A. Ibatici (1) In experimental mouse models, total body irradiation (TBI) plays a critical role facilitating donor BM chimerism and promoting migration of BM cells into several tissues mainly through a radiation damage. The fate of donor-derived BM cells can be tracked by using transgene markers such as the enhanced version of the green fluorescent protein (EGFP). We are interested in the study of cell fusion of BM-derived cells to Purkinje neurons and, in trying to dissect the favouring role of radiation in this process. To this end, we have used an alternative conditioning consisting of the alkylating agent Treosulfan (TREO) which was compared to TBI in an H-2 compatible allogeneic transplant model. Female C57BL/6 (H-2b) were used as recipients. Donor BM cells and splenocytes were obtained from H-2b compatible mice ubiquitously expressing EGFP. Recipients mice received TBI at a total dose of 800 (N=8) or 900 cGy (N=8) on day -1. The alternative conditioning consisted of TREO at 3 different schedules (5000/6000/7000 mg/kg total dose) in association to Fludarabine (FLU) at 300mg/kg total dose, injected intraperitoneally on days -3, -2, -1. TBI and TREO/FLU recipients were transplanted with comparable doses of BM-EGFP+ cells. Donor engraftment was evaluated as percentage of circulating mononuclear EGFP+ cells on day +20 and +40 after transplant. All mice but two were long survivors after transplant. On day+20, donor chimerism of TREO5 (N=5) and TREO6 (N=15) recipients was 3.47 and 18.55%, respectively and increased up to 3-fold following donor splenocytes infusion at a dose of 5 x 10 6 . When we compared TREO7 (N=5) with TBI 800 and 900, there was no difference in the percentage of donor chimerism on day +20 and on day +40 ( fig.1) . Interestingly, chimerism of circulating EGFP+ lymphocytes was significantly higher in the TREO7 group compared to TBI 800 and 900 (79 vs 44 and 49%).

We conclude that TREO7/FLU is a well tolerated regimen in mice, promoting an efficient and sustained donor chimerism. Although TBI remains the most reproducible conditioning in mice, alternative regimens using combination chemotherapy could be taken into account for experimental designs of BM cell plasticity. In fact, the contribution of BM-derived cells into various organs is greatly influenced by tissue injury in a dosedependent manner. Thus, using alternative regimens such as TREO could lead to remarkably different results than using TBI.

Haematopoietic cell transplantation: comorbidity index predicts early transplant mortality S. Van Steenweghen, E. Verburgh, H. De Samblanx ZiekenhuisNetwerkAntwerpen (Antwerp, B) Background: Nonmyeloablative allotransplantregimes enable older patients to undergo hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT). In this population prevalent comorbidities impact on outcome. A focused comorbidityindex (HCT-CI) was recently validated, allowing better prediction of non relapse mortality (NRM) and survival. (Blood. 2005 Oct 15 ; 106 (8) : 2912-9) Frequently disease persists at the moment of conditioning (minimal residual disease, partial remission, persisting disease) for nonmyeloablative allotransplantation. Objective: Is HCT-CI usefull in predicting transplantation risk for patients not in complete remission at transplantation? Method: Analyse time to death and retrospectively application of HCT-CI for patients not in complete remission at transplantation. Results: From 5/2000 to 11/2005 46 consecutive patients received a non myeloablative allotransplant from a HLA identical sibling and with a fludarabin/ATG based conditioning. 20 Patients (43%) died during followup, of which one patient was not evaluable (missing data) and two patients had no evidence of disease at death (true NRM). From the remaining 17 analysed patients, 12 were catalogued as early deaths (<3 months after transplantation) and 5 late deaths. The mean HCT-CI score for early deaths was 3,9 (range 2-6) versus 2,8 (range 0-5) for late deaths. Mean age at transplantation for early deaths was 55 years and for late deaths 61 years, so age does not account for this difference. Conclusion: A short survival after transplantation is more likely with higher HCT-CI.

cite_spans.text: Van Steenweghen, E. Verburgh, H. De Samblanx ZiekenhuisNetwerkAntwerpen (Antwerp, B)
